abstract.text: The superclass for all basic randomization classes in GameplayKit.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The randomization services provided in GameplayKit are suitable for reliably creating deterministic, pseudorandom gameplay mechanics, but are not cryptographically robust. For cryptography, obfuscation, or cipher uses, use the Security framework, described in

In most cases you do not use this class directly; instead, use one of the subclasses listed below. On its own, a random source provides little control over the range or distribution of generated random numbers; to specify such options, use a random source in conjunction with one of the
classes.
When you create an instance of
or one of its subclasses, the resulting random source is both
independent
and
deterministic

—that is, the sequence of numbers generated by one instance has no effect on the sequence generated by another instance, and that sequence can be replicated when necessary. For details on replicating sequences, see each of the random source classes.
Your choice of random source class determines the algorithm used for random number generation:
The
class uses an algorithm similar to that employed in arc4random family of C functions. (However, instances of this class are independent from calls to the arc4random functions.)
The
class uses an algorithm that is faster, but less random, than the
class. (Specifically, the low bits of generated numbers repeat more often than the high bits.) Use this source when performance is more important than robust unpredictability.
The
class uses an algorithm that is slower, but more random, than the
class. Use this source when it’s important that your use of random numbers not show repeating patterns and performance is of less concern.

abstract.text: Architect and organize your game logic. Incorporate common gameplay behaviors such as random number generation, artificial intelligence, pathfinding, and agent behavior.
A basic random number generator implementing the ARC4 algorithm, which is suitable for most gameplay mechanics.
A generator for random numbers that follow a

inlineContent.text: Gaussian distribution

abstract.text: (also known as a

inlineContent.text: normal distribution

abstract.text: ) across multiple samplings.
A basic random number generator implementing the linear congruential generator algorithm, which is faster but less random than the default random source.
A basic random number generator implementing the Mersenne Twister algorithm, which is more random, but slower than the default random source.
The common interface for all randomization classes in (or usable with) GameplayKit.
A generator for random numbers that fall within a specific range and that exhibit a specific distribution over multiple samplings.
The superclass for all basic randomization classes in GameplayKit.
Returns an array whose contents are the same as those of the specified array, but in a random order determined by the random source.
Initializes a new random source object.
Returns a shared instance that shares a system-wide random source.
A generator for random numbers that are uniformly distributed across many samplings, but where short sequences of similar values are unlikely.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
